Middleton attended [[Porter-Gaud School]] and played basketball for the Cyclones under coach John Pearson. As a sophomore, he averaged 12 points and eight rebounds per game.<ref>{{cite news|first=Philip|last=Bowman|url=http://www.postandcourier.com/news/2007/dec/06/overnight_sensation24183/|title=Successful spring rockets Khris Middleton up recruiting rankings|work=[[The Post and Courier]]|publisher=[[Evening Post Publishing Company]]|date=December 6, 2007|access-date=August 28, 2011}}</ref> In his junior season, Middleton posted averages of 21 points and 8.6 rebounds per game and was named state player of the year. He repeated as player of the year as a senior, scoring 22.4 points per game and grabbing 8.6 rebounds per game in leading Porter-Gaud to the state title game.<ref name=TexasA&Mbio/> Middleton was named Most Valuable Player of the Porter-Gaud Holiday Classic, scoring 22 points in the championship.<ref>{{cite news|first=Philip|last=Bowman|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=PZVIAAAAIBAJ&sjid=0AkNAAAAIBAJ&pg=6266,2499232&dq=khris-middleton+porter-gaud&hl=en|title=Middleton Powers Cyclones To Victory|work=[[The Post and Courier]]|publisher=[[Evening Post Publishing Company]]|date=December 23, 2008|access-date=August 31, 2011}}</ref> He was nominated for the [[2009 McDonald's All-American Boys Game]], but was not selected to participate.<ref>{{cite news|first=Philip|last=Bowman|url=http://www.postandcourier.com/news/2009/feb/19/jennings_picked_mcdonalds_all_american_g72287/|title=Jennings picked for McDonald's All-American game|work=[[The Post and Courier]]|publisher=[[Evening Post Publishing Company]]|date=February 19, 2009|access-date=August 31, 2011}}</ref>
 
Middleton attended [[Porter-Gaud School]] and played basketball for the Cyclones under coach John Pearson. As a sophomore, he averaged 12 points and eight rebounds per game.<ref>{{cite news|first=Philip|last=Bowman|url=http://www.postandcourier.com/news/2007/dec/06/overnight_sensation24183/|title=Successful spring rockets Khris Middleton up recruiting rankings|work=[[The Post and Courier]]|publisher=[[Evening Post Publishing Company]]|date=December 6, 2007|access-date=August 28, 2011}}</ref> In his junior season, Middleton posted averages of 21 points and 8.6 rebounds per game and was named state player of the year. He repeated as player of the year as a senior, scoring 22.4 points per game and grabbing 8.6 rebounds per game in leading Porter-Gaud to the state title game.<ref name=TexasA&Mbio/> Middleton was named Most Valuable Player of the Porter-Gaud Holiday Classic, scoring 22 points in the championship.<ref>{{cite news|first=Philip|last=Bowman|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=PZVIAAAAIBAJ&sjid=0AkNAAAAIBAJ&pg=6266,2499232&dq=khris-middleton+porter-gaud&hl=en|title=Middleton Powers Cyclones To Victory|work=[[The Post and Courier]]|publisher=[[Evening Post Publishing Company]]|date=December 23, 2008|access-date=August 31, 2011}}</ref> He was nominated for the [[2009 McDonald's All-American Boys Game]], but was not selected to participate.<ref>{{cite news|first=Philip|last=Bowman|url=http://www.postandcourier.com/news/2009/feb/19/jennings_picked_mcdonalds_all_american_g72287/|title=Jennings picked for McDonald's All-American game|work=[[The Post and Courier]]|publisher=[[Evening Post Publishing Company]]|date=February 19, 2009|access-date=August 31, 2011}}</ref>

Middleton was recruited by [[Texas A&M Aggies men's basketball|Texas A&M]], [[Virginia Tech Hokies men's basketball|Virginia Tech]], [[South Carolina Gamecocks men's basketball|South Carolina]], [[Michigan Wolverines men's basketball|Michigan]], and [[Saint Joseph's Hawks men's basketball|Saint Joseph's]].<ref name=TexasA&Mbio/> He chose Texas A&M, and signed with the Aggies on May 30, 2008. He liked the college town atmosphere, and got along well with the coaching staff.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.postandcourier.com/news/2008/may/30/porter_gauds_middleton_commits_texas_a_a42759/|title=Porter-Gaud's Middleton commits to Texas A&M|work=[[The Post and Courier]]|publisher=[[Evening Post Publishing Company]]|date=May 30, 2008|access-date=August 31, 2011}}</ref>
+
ESPN ranked him the 64th best prospect in the Class of 2009, and noted he was the best shooter at his position. Middleton was recruited by [[Texas A&M Aggies men's basketball|Texas A&M]], [[Virginia Tech Hokies men's basketball|Virginia Tech]], [[South Carolina Gamecocks men's basketball|South Carolina]], [[Michigan Wolverines men's basketball|Michigan]], and [[Saint Joseph's Hawks men's basketball|Saint Joseph's]].<ref name=TexasA&Mbio/> He chose Texas A&M, and signed with the Aggies on May 30, 2008. He liked the college town atmosphere, and got along well with the coaching staff.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.postandcourier.com/news/2008/may/30/porter_gauds_middleton_commits_texas_a_a42759/|title=Porter-Gaud's Middleton commits to Texas A&M|work=[[The Post and Courier]]|publisher=[[Evening Post Publishing Company]]|date=May 30, 2008|access-date=August 31, 2011}}</ref> It is widely known that Kris owes much of his early success to a veteran 8th Grade Literacy teacher from Oshkosh. {{similar names|Christopher Middleton (disambiguation)}}{{short description|American basketball player}}{{Use American English|date=August 2019}} {{Use mdy dates|date=August 2019}} {{Infobox basketball biography | name = Khris Middleton | image = Khris Middleton (39684853532).jpg | caption = Middleton with the [[Milwaukee Bucks]] in 2018 | position = [[Small forward]] | height_ft = 6 | height_in = 7 | weight_lbs = 222 | league = [[National Basketball Association|NBA]] | team = Milwaukee Bucks | number = 22 | nationality = American | birth_date = {{birth date and age|mf=yes|1991|8|12}} | birth_place = [[Charleston, South Carolina]] | highschool = [[Porter-Gaud School|Porter-Gaud]]
(Charleston, South Carolina) | college = [[Texas A&M Aggies men's basketball|Texas A&M]] (2009–2012) | draft_year = 2012 | draft_round = 2 | draft_pick = 39 | draft_team = [[Detroit Pistons]] | career_start = 2012 | career_end = | years1 = {{nbay|2012|full=y}} | team1 = [[Detroit Pistons]] | years2 = [[2012–13 NBA Development League season|2012]] | team2 = →[[Fort Wayne Mad Ants]] | years3 = {{nbay|2013|start}}–present | team3 = [[Milwaukee Bucks]] | team4 = | years4 = | highlights = * 2× [[List of NBA All-Stars|NBA All-Star]] ({{nasg|2019}}, {{nasg|2020}}) * Second-team All-[[Big 12 Conference|Big 12]] ([[2010–11 NCAA Division I men's basketball season|2011]]) | profile = khris_middleton | bbr = middlkh01 }} '''James Khristian Middleton''' (born August 12, 1991) is an American professional [[basketball]] player for the [[Milwaukee Bucks]] of the [[National Basketball Association]] (NBA). He attended high school at the [[Porter-Gaud School]] in [[Charleston, South Carolina]]. As a junior and senior, he was named South Carolina Player of the Year, and was a [[McDonald's All-American]] nominee. After being recruited by [[Scott Spinelli]], he went on to play college basketball for [[Texas A&M University]], where he started the majority of the games in his freshman year. In his sophomore season, he earned second-team All-Big 12 honors after leading the Aggies in scoring with 14.3 points per game. Middleton was selected by the [[Detroit Pistons]] with the 39th overall pick of the [[2012 NBA draft]]. He received his first [[NBA All-Star Game|All-Star]] selection in [[2019 NBA All-Star Game|2019]]. ==Early life and high school== Middleton was born on August 12, 1991 in [[Charleston, South Carolina]] to James and Nichelle Middleton. He has one older sister named Brittney, and his cousin, [[Josh Powell]], has played in the NBA. Another cousin, Kenny Manigault, played basketball for [[Wichita State University]] and was teammates with Middleton on the [[Amateur Athletic Union]] (AAU) team Carolina Celtics.{{cite news|first=Philip|last=Bowman|url=http://www.postandcourier.com/news/2008/aug/06/pinewood_star_manigault_commits_wichita_49879/|title=Pinewood star Manigault commits to Wichita State|work=[[The Post and Courier]]|publisher=[[Evening Post Publishing Company]]|date=August 6, 2008|access-date=August 30, 2011}} Two other teammates on the Carolina Celtics accepted Division I basketball scholarships, Jamal Curry ([[Radford Highlanders men's basketball|Radford]]) and [[Devin Booker (basketball, born 1991)|Devin Booker]] ([[Clemson Tigers men's basketball|Clemson]]).{{cite web|url=http://www.aggieathletics.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=27300&ATCLID=205236051 |title=#22 Khris Middleton |work=[[Texas A&M Aggies]] |publisher=[[Texas A&M University]] |access-date=August 18, 2011 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120527200850/http://www.aggieathletics.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=27300&ATCLID=205236051 |archive-date=May 27, 2012 }} Middleton attended [[Porter-Gaud School]] and played basketball for the Cyclones under coach John Pearson. As a sophomore, he averaged 12 points and eight rebounds per game.{{cite news|first=Philip|last=Bowman|url=http://www.postandcourier.com/news/2007/dec/06/overnight_sensation24183/|title=Successful spring rockets Khris Middleton up recruiting rankings|work=[[The Post and Courier]]|publisher=[[Evening Post Publishing Company]]|date=December 6, 2007|access-date=August 28, 2011}} In his junior season, Middleton posted averages of 21 points and 8.6 rebounds per game and was named state player of the year. He repeated as player of the year as a senior, scoring 22.4 points per game and grabbing 8.6 rebounds per game in leading Porter-Gaud to the state title game. Middleton was named Most Valuable Player of the Porter-Gaud Holiday Classic, scoring 22 points in the championship.{{cite news|first=Philip|last=Bowman|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=PZVIAAAAIBAJ&sjid=0AkNAAAAIBAJ&pg=6266,2499232&dq=khris-middleton+porter-gaud&hl=en|title=Middleton Powers Cyclones To Victory|work=[[The Post and Courier]]|publisher=[[Evening Post Publishing Company]]|date=December 23, 2008|access-date=August 31, 2011}} He was nominated for the [[2009 McDonald's All-American Boys Game]], but was not selected to participate.{{cite news|first=Philip|last=Bowman|url=http://www.postandcourier.com/news/2009/feb/19/jennings_picked_mcdonalds_all_american_g72287/|title=Jennings picked for McDonald's All-American game|work=[[The Post and Courier]]|publisher=[[Evening Post Publishing Company]]|date=February 19, 2009|access-date=August 31, 2011}} ESPN ranked him the 64th best prospect in the Class of 2009, and noted he was the best shooter at his position. Middleton was recruited by [[Texas A&M Aggies men's basketball|Texas A&M]], [[Virginia Tech Hokies men's basketball|Virginia Tech]], [[South Carolina Gamecocks men's basketball|South Carolina]], [[Michigan Wolverines men's basketball|Michigan]], and [[Saint Joseph's Hawks men's basketball|Saint Joseph's]]. He chose Texas A&M, and signed with the Aggies on May 30, 2008. He liked the college town atmosphere, and got along well with the coaching staff.{{cite news|url=http://www.postandcourier.com/news/2008/may/30/porter_gauds_middleton_commits_texas_a_a42759/|title=Porter-Gaud's Middleton commits to Texas A&M|work=[[The Post and Courier]]|publisher=[[Evening Post Publishing Company]]|date=May 30, 2008|access-date=August 31, 2011}} It is widely known that Kris owes much of his early success to a veteran 8th Grade Literacy teacher from Oshkosh. Also, it is rumored that Kris really hates anyone named Sophia. {{College athlete recruit start|40=no|collapse=no|year=2005}} {{College athlete recruit entry | recruit = Khris Middleton | position = [[Small forward|SF]] | hometown = Charleston, South Carolina | highschool = [[Porter-Gaud School]] | feet = 6 | inches = 7 | weight = 217 | 40 = | commitdate = May 30, 2008 | scout stars = 3 | rivals stars = 3 | espn grade = 91 }} {{College athlete recruit end | 40 = | year = 2009 | rivals ref title = Texas A&M Basketball Commitments | scout ref title = 2009 Texas A&M Basketball Commits | espn ref title = | rivals school = tamu | scout s = 186 | espn schoolid = | scout overall = 30 (SF) | rivals overall = 29 (SF) | accessdate = August 28, 2011 | bball = yes }} ==College career== ===Freshman year=== Middleton was recruited by then Texas A&M assistant coach [[Scott Spinelli]]. Coming into his freshman year, Middleton expected to fill the [[three-point shot|three point shooting]] void of departed senior [[Josh Carter]]. Middleton's college career started slowly, connecting on 1-of-12 [[field goal (basketball)|field goals]] in limited action of his first three games.{{cite news|first=Brent|last=Zwerneman|url=http://www.chron.com/sports/college/article/Freshman-Middleton-in-middle-of-action-for-A-M-men-1708248.php|title=Freshman Middleton in middle of action for A&M men|work=[[Houston Chronicle]]|publisher=[[Hearst Corporation]]|date=February 13, 2010|access-date=August 31, 2011}} After a season-ending leg injury to Derrick Roland on December 11, 2009, Middleton was forced to take a larger role in the offense and started 18 of the last 20 games. On February 3, 2010, he scored 16 points to help Texas A&M erase an 11-point second half deficit to defeat [[2009–10 Missouri Tigers men's basketball team|Missouri]] 77–74.{{cite news|first=Steve|last=Walentik|url=http://www.columbiatribune.com/news/2011/jan/15/well-worth-the-wait/|title=A&M's Middleton no longer a surprise|work=[[Columbia Daily Tribune]]|date=January 15, 2011|access-date=September 1, 2011|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120404022810/http://www.columbiatribune.com/news/2011/jan/15/well-worth-the-wait/|archive-date=April 4, 2012}} In a 69-53 [[2010 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|NCAA Tournament]] Round of 64 victory over [[2009–10 Utah State Aggies men's basketball team|Utah State]], Middleton scored a season-high 19 points on 7-of-10 shooting.{{cite news|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=300780245|title=Middleton helps Texas A&M snag fifth straight opening round win|agency=[[Associated Press]]|work=[[ESPN]]|publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures|date=March 19, 2010|access-date=September 2, 2011}} Texas A&M's season ended with a loss in the Round of 32 to [[2009–10 Purdue Boilermakers men's basketball team|Purdue]]; the Aggies finished with a record of 24–10.{{cite news|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=300802509|title=Kramer takes over to lead Purdue to sixth Sweet 16 in 12 appearances|agency=[[Associated Press]]|work=[[ESPN]]|publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures|date=March 21, 2010|access-date=September 2, 2011}} Overall, Khris Middleton averaged 7.2 points and 3.7 rebounds per game and led the team in scoring five times. ===Sophomore year=== As a sophomore, Middleton led the team and finished ninth in the Big 12 in scoring at 14.3 points per game while also contributing 5.2 rebounds per game. He hit 45 percent of his shots from the floor and 78.4 percent of his [[free throws]]. Middleton scored in excess of 10 points in 27 games and led the team in scoring 16 times. He scored a career-high 31 points in a 71–62 overtime victory over [[2010–11 Arkansas Razorbacks men's basketball team|Arkansas]], including 11 of the team's last 12 points in regulation. This earned him Big 12 Player of the Week and Oscar Robertson National Player of the Week honors for the week of December 13–19, 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.sportswriters.net/usbwa/news/2011/oscar101221.html|work=[[United States Basketball Writers Association|U.S. Basketball Writers Association]]|title=Texas A&M's Middleton is Oscar Robertson National Player of the Week|access-date=September 20, 2011|date=December 21, 2010}} On January 15, 2011, Middleton tallied 28 points, including 11 in overtime, to defeat [[2010–11 Missouri Tigers men's basketball team|Missouri]] 91–89.{{cite news|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=310150245|agency=[[Associated Press]]|work=[[ESPN]]|publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures|title=Khris Middleton tallies 11 points in OT as Aggies take out Tigers|access-date=October 29, 2011|date=January 15, 2011}} Middleton-led Texas A&M went 24-9 and lost in the [[2011 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|NCAA Tournament]] Round of 64 to [[2010–11 Florida State Seminoles men's basketball team|Florida State]] 57–50, in a contest in which Middleton contributed 16 points.{{cite news|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=310770245|agency=[[Associated Press]]|work=[[ESPN]]|publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures|title=Florida State picks up first tournament win since 1998|access-date=October 29, 2011|date=March 18, 2011}} He was selected to the All-Big 12 Second Team at the conclusion of the regular season.{{cite web|url=http://www.big12sports.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=10410&ATCLID=205110225|title=2011 Phillips 66 All-Big 12 Men's Basketball Awards Announced|work=[[Big 12 Conference]]|date=March 6, 2011|access-date=October 29, 2011}} The [[United States Basketball Writers Association|U.S. Basketball Writers Association]] named Middleton to the 10-man All-District VII team covering college basketball players in the states of Texas, Arkansas, and Louisiana.{{cite web|url=http://www.sportswriters.net/usbwa/news/2011/alldistrict110310.html|work=[[United States Basketball Writers Association|U.S. Basketball Writers Association]]|title=USBWA Names 2010–11 Men's All-District Teams|access-date=June 20, 2011|date=March 10, 2011}} He was recognized as an All-Eighth District second-team selection by the [[National Association of Basketball Coaches]] making him eligible for the State Farm Division I All‐America teams.{{cite web|url=http://www.nabc.org/photos/schools/nabc/sports/m-baskbl/auto_pdf/D1AllDistrict2011.pdf| publisher=[[National Association of Basketball Coaches]]| title=National Association of Basketball Coaches Announces 2011 Division I All-District Teams|access-date=March 23, 2011|date=March 9, 2011}} Since the Big 12 Conference was its own district, this is equivalent to being named second team All-Big 12 by the NABC.{{cite web|url=http://www.nabc.org/awards/all_district/2008-09NABCDistrictRealignm|title=2008–09 NABC Division I Men's Basketball District Realignment|access-date=July 19, 2010|work=[[National Association of Basketball Coaches]]}} ===Junior year=== [[File:Khris Middleton.jpg|thumb|left|Middleton playing against Iowa State in 2012]] Prior to Middleton's junior season, head coach [[Mark Turgeon]] left to take the same position at the [[University of Maryland]] and was replaced by [[Billy Kennedy (basketball)|Billy Kennedy]] of [[Murray State Racers men's basketball|Murray State]]. Middleton was impressed with Kennedy's coaching acumen and chose to remain an Aggie.{{cite news|first=Jimmy|last=Burch|url=http://www.star-telegram.com/2011/07/07/3207616/new-texas-ams-new-basketball-coach.html|title=New Texas A&M's new basketball coach will install faster pace|work=[[Fort Worth Star-Telegram]]|publisher=[[The McClatchy Company]]|date=July 7, 2011|access-date=August 28, 2011}} He was listed on the preseason watchlist for the [[Wooden Award]].{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/mens-college-basketball/story/_/id/7053604/opposing-coaches-break-50-players-wooden-award-watch-list-college-basketball|title=Scouting the Wooden Award watch list|work=[[ESPN]]|publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures|date=October 3, 2011|access-date=October 29, 2011}} Middleton was a unanimous choice to the preseason All-Big 12 team.{{cite web|url=http://www.big12sports.com/ViewArticle.dbml?SPSID=106110&SPID=13134&DB_LANG=C&DB_OEM_ID=10410&ATCLID=205312119|title=Preseason All-Big 12 Men's Basketball Honors Announced|work=[[Big 12 Conference]]|date=October 6, 2011|access-date=October 29, 2011}} Despite being the preseason co-favorite in the league, Texas A&M finished 14-18 overall and 4–14 in the [[Big 12 Conference|Big 12]]. The team was hampered by a rash of injuries, including a knee injury that forced Middleton to sit for 12 games. He averaged 13.2 points and 5.0 rebounds per game, down from the previous season. On April 9, 2012, Middleton declared for the NBA Draft, forgoing his final season of collegiate eligibility. He thanked Texas A&M in a statement.{{cite news|url=http://espn.go.com/nba/draft2012/story/_/id/7794122/2012-nba-draft-khris-middleton-texas-aggies-declares|title=Khris Middleton declares for draft|access-date=July 9, 2015|date=April 10, 2012|publisher=[[ESPN]]|agency=[[Associated Press]]}} ==Professional career== ===Detroit Pistons (2012–2013)=== Middleton was selected by the [[Detroit Pistons]] with the 39th overall pick in the [[2012 NBA draft]]. On August 15, 2012, he signed his rookie scale contract with the Pistons.[http://www.nba.com/pistons/news/detroit-pistons-sign-second-round-draft-selection-khris-middleton Detroit Pistons Sign Second Round Draft Selection Khris Middleton] On December 12, 2012, he was assigned to the [[Fort Wayne Mad Ants]] of the [[NBA Development League]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/pistons/news/detroit-pistons-assign-khris-middleton-and-kim-english-fort-wayne-mad-ants|title=Detroit Pistons Assign Khris Middleton And Kim English To Fort Wayne Mad Ants|work=NBA.com|date=December 12, 2012|access-date=December 12, 2012}} A week later, he was recalled by the Pistons.{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/pistons/news/detroit-pistons-recall-khris-middleton-and-kim-english-fort-wayne-mad-ants|title=Detroit Pistons Recall Khris Middleton and Kim English from Fort Wayne Mad Ants|work=NBA.com|date=December 19, 2012|access-date=December 19, 2012}} He finished his rookie season having managed just 27 games for the Pistons while averaging 6.1 points, 1.9 rebounds and 1.0 assists in 17.6 minutes per game. ===Milwaukee Bucks (2013–present)=== On July 31, 2013, Middleton was traded, along with [[Brandon Knight (basketball)|Brandon Knight]] and [[Viacheslav Kravtsov]], to the [[Milwaukee Bucks]] in exchange for guard [[Brandon Jennings]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/bucks/release/bucks-acquire-knight-middleton-and-kravtsov-pistons|title=Bucks Acquire Knight, Middleton and Kravtsov from Pistons|date=July 31, 2013|work=NBA.com|publisher=Turner Sports Interactive, Inc.|access-date=August 2, 2013}} In contrast to his limited action in 2012–13, Middleton played all 82 games in 2013–14, while starting 64 and averaging 12.1 points, 3.8 rebounds, 2.1 assists and 1.0 steals in 30.0 minutes per game. On December 6, 2013, he scored a then career-high 29 points in a 109–105 win over the [[Washington Wizards]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/games/20131206/MILWAS/gameinfo.html|title=Notebook: Bucks 109, Wizards 105|date=December 6, 2013|work=NBA.com|publisher=Turner Sports Interactive, Inc.|access-date=December 16, 2014}} On December 15, 2014, the Bucks were down by one to the [[Phoenix Suns]] with under four seconds remaining in regulation as Middleton hit a contested game-winning buzzer beater to defeat the Suns, 96–94, with Middleton finishing with 14 points.{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/games/20141215/MILPHX/gameinfo.html|title=Middleton's late shot helps Bucks beat Suns 96-94|date=December 15, 2014|work=NBA.com|publisher=Turner Sports Interactive, Inc.|access-date=December 16, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141228003205/http://www.nba.com/games/20141215/MILPHX/gameinfo.html|archive-date=December 28, 2014|url-status=dead}} On March 7, 2015, he scored a then-career-high 30 points on 11-of-20 shooting in a 91–85 win over the Washington Wizards.[http://www.brewhoop.com/2015/3/7/8169043/bucks-vs-wizards-final-score-khris-middleton-career-high-john-wall Bucks vs. Wizards final score: Khris Middleton's career night shoots Milwaukee past Washington, 91-85] In his second season with the Bucks, Middleton emerged as an important "3-and-D" player, shooting 46.7 percent from the floor and 40.7 percent from behind the three-point arc. He averaged 13.4 points, 4.4 rebounds and 2.3 assists per game.{{cite news|last1=Herbert|first1=James|title=Report: Bucks, Khris Middleton agree to 5-year, $70 million deal|url=http://www.cbssports.com/nba/eye-on-basketball/25230079/report-bucks-khris-middleton-nearing-5-year-70-million-deal|access-date=July 9, 2015|work=[[CBS Sports]]|date=July 1, 2015}} On July 9, 2015, Middleton re-signed with the Bucks to a five-year, $70 million contract, with a player option for the fifth year. This constituted a significant pay raise for Middleton, as he earned $915,000 the prior year.{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/bucks/release/bucks-re-sign-khris-middleton|title=BUCKS RE-SIGN KHRIS MIDDLETON|work=NBA.com|date=July 9, 2015|access-date=July 11, 2015}} On December 29, 2015, in a loss to the Oklahoma City Thunder, he scored a career-high 36 points on 13-of-22 from the field and 6-of-9 from three-point range.{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/games/20151229/MILOKC/gameinfo.html|title=Westbrook and Durant lead Thunder over Bucks 131-123|work=NBA.com|date=December 29, 2015|access-date=December 29, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151230041927/http://www.nba.com/games/20151229/MILOKC/gameinfo.html|archive-date=December 30, 2015|url-status=dead}} On March 4, 2016, in a win over the Minnesota Timberwolves, he scored 32 points on 11-of-16 shooting, including 8-of-9 on three-pointers, marking the most three-pointers made by a Bucks player since [[Carlos Delfino]] had eight on March 18, 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/games/20160304/MINMIL/gameinfo.html|title=Antetokounmpo leads Bucks to 116-101 win over Timberwolves|work=NBA.com|date=March 4, 2016|access-date=March 5, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303130456/http://www.nba.com/games/20160304/MINMIL/gameinfo.html|archive-date=March 3, 2016|url-status=dead}} He tied his career high of 36 points on April 10, 2016, in a 109–108 overtime win over the Philadelphia 76ers.{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/games/20160410/MILPHI/gameinfo.html|title=Middleton scores 36, lifts Bucks past 76ers 109-108 in OT|work=NBA.com|date=April 10, 2016|access-date=April 10, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160413103900/http://www.nba.com/games/20160410/MILPHI/gameinfo.html|archive-date=April 13, 2016|url-status=dead}} On September 21, 2016, Middleton was ruled out for six months after sustaining a left hamstring injury in preseason workouts that required surgery.{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/bucks/news/khris-middleton-sidelined-hamstring-injury|title=KHRIS MIDDLETON SIDELINED WITH HAMSTRING INJURY|work=NBA.com|date=September 21, 2016|access-date=September 21, 2016}} On February 8, 2017, he made his season debut after missing the first 50 games with the hamstring injury, scoring five points in 15 minutes in a 106–88 loss to the [[Miami Heat]].{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/nba/recap?gameId=400900192|title=Miami Heat extend win streak to 12, beat Bucks 106-88|work=ESPN.com|date=February 8, 2017|access-date=February 9, 2017}} On March 17, 2017, he scored 14 of his season-high 30 points in the fourth quarter of the Bucks' 107–103 win over the [[Los Angeles Lakers]].{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/nba/recap?gameId=400900422|title=Bucks hold off Lakers 107-103 after 3 ejections for shoving|work=ESPN.com|date=March 17, 2017|access-date=March 18, 2017}} On November 1, 2017, Middleton scored a then career-high 43 points in a 126–121 loss to the [[Charlotte Hornets]].{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/nba/recap?gameId=400974856|title=Walker, Monk lead Hornets past Bucks 126-121|work=ESPN.com|date=November 1, 2017|access-date=November 1, 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.cbssports.com/fantasy/basketball/news/bucks-khris-middleton-drops-career-high-43-points-on-hornets/|title=Bucks' Khris Middleton: Drops career-high 43 points on Hornets|work=cbssports.com|date=November 2, 2017|access-date=November 2, 2017}} On November 22, 2017, he scored 40 points in a 113–107 overtime win over the Phoenix Suns.{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/nba/recap?gameId=400975015|title=Middleton scores 40 points, Bucks beat Suns in OT|work=ESPN.com|date=November 22, 2017|access-date=November 22, 2017}} On January 20, 2018, he had his first career-triple double with 23 points, 14 rebounds and 10 assists in a 116–94 loss to the [[Philadelphia 76ers]].{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/nba/recap?gameId=400975424|title=Embiid, 76ers power past Bucks 116-94 and into 6th in East|work=ESPN.com|date=January 20, 2018|access-date=January 20, 2018}} In Game 1 of the Bucks' first-round playoff series against the [[Boston Celtics]], Middleton had 31 points, eight rebounds and six assists in a 113–107 overtime loss.{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/nba/recap?gameId=401029429|title=Celtics survive wild finish, hold off Bucks 113-107 in OT|work=ESPN.com|date=April 15, 2018|access-date=April 15, 2018}} The Bucks went on to lose the series in seven games, despite Middleton's 32 points in a 112–96 loss in Game 7.{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/nba/recap?gameId=401029437|title=Celtics beat Bucks 112-96 in Game 7, advance to play 76ers|work=ESPN.com|date=April 28, 2018|access-date=April 28, 2018}} On October 22, 2018, Middleton hit 7 of 8 3-pointers and finished with 30 points in a 124–113 win over the [[New York Knicks]].{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/nba/recap?gameId=401070723|title=Giannis, Middleton hit late 3s, Bucks hold off Knicks|work=ESPN.com|date=October 22, 2018|access-date=October 22, 2018}} On December 29, despite a quad injury, Middleton scored 29 points in a 129–115 win over the [[Brooklyn Nets]].{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/nba/recap?gameId=401071203|title=Giannis' triple-double helps Bucks turn away Nets 129-115|work=ESPN.com|date=December 29, 2018|access-date=December 30, 2018}} On January 31, 2019, Middleton was named an Eastern Conference All-Star reserve, thus earning his first All-Star selection.{{cite web|url=https://www.nba.com/bucks/release/khris-middleton-selected-2019-nba-all-star-game|title=Khris Middleton Selected to 2019 NBA All-Star Game|work=NBA.com|date=January 31, 2019|access-date=February 1, 2019}} On February 21, 2019, he had 15 points and a season-high 13 rebounds in a 98–97 win over the Celtics.{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/nba/recap?gameId=401071543|title=Antetokounmpo scores 30 points, Bucks beat Celtics 98-97|work=ESPN.com|date=February 21, 2019|access-date=February 22, 2019}} On March 28, he scored a season-high 39 points in a 128–118 win over the [[Los Angeles Clippers]].{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/nba/recap?gameId=401071800|title=Giannis paces Bucks with 34, exits with hurt ankle|work=ESPN.com|date=March 28, 2019|access-date=March 29, 2019}} Following the 2018–19 season, Middleton signed a five-year, $178 million contract extension with Milwaukee.{{Cite web|url=https://www.spotrac.com/nba/milwaukee-bucks/khris-middleton-10864/|title=Khris Middleton|last=Spotrac.com|website=Spotrac.com|language=en-US|access-date=2019-07-09}} On January 28, 2020, Middleton set a new career-high, scoring 51 points, making 16 of 26 shots, including 7 of 10 on 3-pointers, in a 151–131 victory over the [[Washington Wizards]]. After the game, Middleton dedicated his performance to [[Kobe Bryant]], who died two days prior in a California helicopter crash, saying “I definitely can dedicate that game to him as a thank you for what he did for the game”.{{cite news |last1=Woodyard |first1=Eric |title=Without Giannis, Khris Middleton's career night carries Bucks |url=https://www.espn.com/nba/story/_/id/28589331/without-giannis-khris-middleton-career-night-carries-bucks |access-date=January 29, 2020 |work=[[ESPN]] |date=January 29, 2020}} On January 30, 2020, Middleton was named an Eastern Conference All-Star reserve, thus earning his second consecutive All-Star selection. https://www.nba.com/amp/bucks/news/khris-middleton-earns-all-star-selection-second-consecutive-season On February 24, Middleton scored 40 points in a 137–134 overtime win over the Wizards. https://www.cbssports.com/fantasy/basketball/news/bucks-khris-middleton-explodes-for-40-points/amp/ Middleton missed a game against the [[Oklahoma City Thunder]] on February 28 due to neck soreness.{{cite news |last1=Velazquez |first1=Matt |title=Khris Middleton is out against the Oklahoma City Thunder due to sore neck |url=https://www.jsonline.com/story/sports/nba/bucks/2020/02/28/bucks-khris-middleton-out-thunder-game-sore-neck/4908594002/ |access-date=March 1, 2020 |work=[[Milwaukee Journal-Sentinel]] |date=February 28, 2020}} In the postseason, Middleton and the Bucks were eliminated in the Semi-Finals by the eventual Eastern Conference champion [[2019–20 Miami Heat season|Miami Heat]] in five games. https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/08/sports/basketball/nba-milwaukee-bucks-miami-heat-giannis.html Middleton scored a playoff career-high 36 points, along with 8 rebounds and 8 assists, in the lone Milwaukee victory in Game 4. https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/06/sports/basketball/bucks-heat-nba-playoffs.html ==Career statistics== {{NBA player statistics legend}} ===NBA=== ====Regular Middleton is a Christian.{{cite news|last1=Middleton|first1=Khris|title=Charleston Strong|url=http://www.theplayerstribune.com/emanuel-ame-church-charleston-khris-middleton/|access-date=July 9, 2015|work=[[The Players' Tribune]]|date=July 7, 2015}} On July 7, 2015, Middleton penned a column in [[The Players' Tribune]] about the [[Charleston church shooting]]. He explained that the shooting affected him deeply because he grew up in Charleston and his grandmother Juanita knew four of the nine people who died. Middleton had met one of the victims, Cynthia Hurd, as she dropped her nephew off at a basketball camp not long before the shooting. "In Charleston, we're staying strong, but the wounds are still deep," he wrote. On April 23, 2019 Middleton and his girlfriend Samantha Dutton welcomed their first daughter, Audrielle. In order to be there for the birth, Middleton got on a plane to Milwaukee with Bucks co-owner [[Marc Lasry]] immediately after a playoff win over the [[Detroit Pistons]]. {{cite news |last1=Velazquez |first1=Matt |title=A clinch missed, a surprise ride on Marc Lasry's jet and a harrowing drive got Khris Middleton home for his daughter's birth |url=https://www.jsonline.com/story/sports/nba/bucks/2019/06/15/clinch-missed-surprise-ride-marc-lasrys-jet-and-harrowing-drive-got-khris-middleton-home-his-daughte/1436260001/ |access-date=August 21, 2020 |work=[[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel]] |date=June 15, 2019}} On March 13, 2020, Middleton said he would match [[Giannis Antetokounmpo]]'s $100,000 donation to the staff of the Fiserv Forum who were unable to work during the suspension of the 2019–20 NBA season because of the [[COVID-19 pandemic]].{{cite web |last1=Herzog |first1=Kaitlyn |title='We can get through this together:' Giannis, Middleton donate $100K each to Fiserv Forum staff, Bucks to match |url=https://fox6now.com/2020/03/13/we-can-get-through-this-together-giannis-donates-100000-to-fiserv-forum-staff/ |access-date=March 15, 2020}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{commons category}} {{basketballstats|nba=khris_middleton|bbr=m/middlkh01}} *[http://www.nba.com/bucks/roster/khris-middleton Milwaukee
